timeline.message:
Add yaml dependencies and FilePropertiesSpec

- add jackson databind, yaml dependencies
- add first parseable portion of buildfile
- add `Instants` class which may be removed later

timeline.bodyText: I see there are no setters. Can these be final?
timeline.author: chanseokoh
timeline.diffHunk:

See the + * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under + * the License. + */ + +package com.google.cloud.tools.jib.cli.buildfile; + +import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonCreator; +import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonProperty; +import com.google.cloud.tools.jib.api.buildplan.FilePermissions; +import java.time.Instant; +import java.util.Optional; +import javax.annotation.Nullable; + +/** + * A yaml block for specifying file properties (used in conjunction with layers). + * + *

Example use of this yaml snippet. + * + * 

{@code
+ * filePermissions: 644
+ * directoryPermissions: 755
+ * user: foo
+ * group: bar
+ * timestamp: 100
+ * }
+ */ +public class FilePropertiesSpec { + @Nullable private FilePermissions filePermissions; + @Nullable private FilePermissions directoryPermissions; + @Nullable private String user; + @Nullable private String group; + @Nullable private Instant timestamp;

replies.bodyText: Yeah actually I think so, I was using a different jackson mechanism to load the values, but since I'm using @JsonCreator now, final seems possible, let me test it out.
replies.author: loosebazooka

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               * Parses a string into Instant, string must be time in millis or iso8601 datetime.
          
          
            
               *
          
          
            
               * @param time in millis or is8601 format
          
          
            
               * @param fieldName name of field being parse (for error messaging)
          
          
            
               * Parses a string into Instant. The string must be time in millis since the epoch or iso8601 datetime.
          
          
            
               *
          
          
            
               * @param time in millis since the epoch or iso8601 format
          
          
            
               * @param fieldName name of field being parsed (for error messaging)

+import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
+import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatterBuilder;
+import java.time.format.DateTimeParseException;
+
+/** Helper class to convert various strings to Instants. */
+public class Instants {
+  /**
+   * Parses a string into Instant, string must be time in millis or iso8601 datetime.
+   *
+   * @param time in millis or is8601 format
+   * @param fieldName name of field being parse (for error messaging)

timeline.bodyText:
It's a matter of preference, but it's possible to assign the instance in the field declaration (and with final). This makes sense too because the code is long.
And does any test fail if we don't have FAIL_ON_IGNORED_PROPERTIES set?
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: Actually when I took apart these tests, I meant to use (FAIL_ON_UNKNOWN_PROPERTIES, true), but it looks like the default value for those is true anyway. So this doesn't do anything useful. Moving to field declaration. Good Catch.
replies.author: loosebazooka

timeline.bodyText: QQ: is this ("") only for better alignment?
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText: yeah I think so when I wrote this, but I don't think that's a great reason. Removed this.
replies.author: loosebazooka

+

+import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatter;
+import java.time.format.DateTimeFormatterBuilder;
